Question: I need to prepare lessons on virtualization, with a focus on full virtualization, para-virtualization, and hardware-supported virtualization. Include how each method works, the role of hypervisors (Type 1 and Type 2), and performance implications.

Core_Concepts.Definition: Provides a virtual machine that fully simulates all the hardware of the underlying device.
Key_Points: Simulates all hardware components of the underlying device.
Creates a complete virtual environment independent of the host system.
Offers isolation and security for virtual machines.
Core_Concepts.Significance_Detail: Offers complete isolation and control over the virtual machine's hardware, enabling the running of different operating systems and applications.
Core_Concepts.Weaknesses: Can be computationally expensive due to the need for full hardware emulation.

Core_Concepts.Definition: Uses existing hardware resources without full emulation.
Key_Points: Runs alongside the host operating system on the same physical machine.
Virtualizes only the operating system kernel and drivers.
Offers improved performance compared to full virtualization.
Core_Concepts.Significance_Detail: Reduces performance overhead compared to full virtualization by sharing hardware resources with the host system.
Core_Concepts.Strengths: Offers better performance and resource utilization efficiency.
Core_Concepts.Weaknesses: Less isolation and security compared to full virtualization.

Core_Concepts.Definition: Utilizes hardware-assisted features in CPUs to enhance virtualization performance.
Key_Points: Leverages CPU extensions like Intel VT-x and AMD-V
Reduces the need for software-based emulation.
Core_Concepts.Significance_Detail: Provides efficient resource utilization and enhances performance by offloading virtualization tasks to hardware.
Core_Concepts.Weaknesses: Hardware support may not be available on all CPUs.

Overall_Summary: Virtualization methods enable the creation of isolated virtual environments by simulating hardware or sharing resources, offering improved performance and resource utilization compared to traditional operating system configurations.
